Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Disparity of Coherence and Channel Information in Wireless Networks - Opportunities and Challenges

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Due to the increasing demand on wireless spectrum and empowered by continued improvements in circuit technology, the performance limits of wireless networks as well as methods that hold the promise of approaching these limits remain a vital topic of inquiry. Many of the advanced techniques in wireless communication are increasingly dependent on the knowledge of link qualities (channel state information) being acquired and properly exchanged among the nodes. This task is closely dependent on how rapidly the corresponding channel gains vary (coherence intervals). Link coherence intervals may easily be different due to variations in node speeds or differences in scattering environment, but a fundamental characterization of the performance limits of networks under link coherence disparity has not been available thus far. This project exploits additional degrees of freedom that coherency disparity exposes, thus increasing spectral efficiency in wireless communication networks. The research plan is tightly coupled with educational outreach activities that seek to foster inclusiveness in STEM fields.

This project initiates a fundamental study of the effects of coherence disparity on wireless networks, addressing prototype building blocks of wireless networks, their performance limits under coherence disparity, and efficient methods of capturing gains in this scenario. The project has the following main components: (1) Study of broadcast channels and multiple-access channels under coherence disparity, including multi-user extensions and outer bounds; (2) Study of frequency-selective channels and orthogonal frequency-division multiplex (OFDM) resource reuse under coherence disparity; and (3) Study of relay and cooperative networks under coherence disparity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless communication continues to permeate our everyday lives, its presence extending to many application domains. Many devices and applications reside within the scope of this communication with different physical wave propagation characteristics due to the speed of nodes and the composition of their environment. (See Figure 1). This project analyzed the effect of the disparity of fading dynamics in the wireless environment as the source of new and formerly unexplored phenomena that can be utilized to improve the performance of wireless communications. Following promising preliminary results, this project made significant advances in both analysis and synthesis of communication techniques using a new tool for communication under fading disparity, known as product superposition. The downlink and uplink communication whose fading links have differing time coherence intervals were studied in this project, obtaining results that address a number of scenarios with increasing levels of generality and sophistication. Another of the key outcomes of this project was the analysis of multi-user communication when fading links experience different coherence bandwidth. This result is relevant to the multiuser communication under OFDM, a ubiquitous component of the air interface in wireless communication. Finally, a mode of wireless communication using relays, also known as cooperative communication, was studied when fading links experience different coherence times.

Through this project, the understanding of fading wireless channels has been significantly enhanced, and the groundwork has been laid to improve the performance of wireless communication systems in scenarios where multiple links with varying fading coherence time or coherence frequency coexist.
